articles.headline: Trump’s Tariffs, Once Seen as Leverage, May Be Here to Stay
articles.snippet: The president’s latest trade measures have left the United States with the highest tariff rate among the most developed countries, outranking Canada, Germany, Russia and even China.
articles.abstract: The president’s latest trade measures have left the United States with the highest tariff rate among the most developed countries, outranking Canada, Germany, Russia and even China.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s tariffs were initially seen as a cudgel to force other countries to drop their trade barriers. But they increasingly look like a more permanent tool to shelter American industry, block imports and banish an undesirable trade deficit.

articles.headline: Before Ethiopian Crash, Boeing Resisted Pilots’ Calls for Aggressive Steps on 737 Max
articles.snippet: In a tense meeting with American Airlines pilots shortly after the first deadly crash of Boeing’s new jet, executives insisted that the plane was safe to fly.
articles.abstract: In a tense meeting with American Airlines pilots shortly after the first deadly crash of Boeing’s new jet, executives insisted that the plane was safe to fly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Weeks after the first fatal crash of the 737 Max, pilots from American Airlines pressed Boeing executives to work urgently on a fix. In a closed-door meeting, they even argued that Boeing should push authorities to take an emergency measure that would likely result in the grounding of the Max.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Natalie Kitroeff

articles.headline: San Francisco Bans Facial Recognition Technology
articles.snippet: It is the first ban by a major city on the use of facial recognition technology by the police and all other municipal agencies.
articles.abstract: It is the first ban by a major city on the use of facial recognition technology by the police and all other municipal agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — San Francisco, long at the heart of the technology revolution, took a stand against potential abuse on Tuesday by banning the use of facial recognition software by the police and other agencies.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger, Richard Fausset and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: At the N.R.A., a Cash Machine Sputtering
articles.snippet: As the gun rights group lavished pay and perks on its leaders and partners, fueling infighting, it increasingly relied on its own charity for funds. Tax experts have questions.
articles.abstract: As the gun rights group lavished pay and perks on its leaders and partners, fueling infighting, it increasingly relied on its own charity for funds. Tax experts have questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tantalizing leaks have spilled out in the weeks since the National Rifle Association’s annual convention in Indianapolis devolved into civil war.

articles.headline: Skeptical U.S. Allies Resist Trump’s New Claims of Threats From Iran
articles.snippet: The Trump administration is laying the groundwork for major military action against Iran, but it may have a hard time rallying domestic and international support.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration is laying the groundwork for major military action against Iran, but it may have a hard time rallying domestic and international support.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Trump administration draws up war plans against Iran over what it says are threats to American troops and interests, a senior British military official told reporters at the Pentagon on Tuesday that he saw no increased risk from Iran or allied militias in Iraq or Syria.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Edward Wong

articles.headline: Facebook Restricts Live Streaming After New Zealand Shooting
articles.snippet: When 51 people were killed in New Zealand, the suspect broadcast it live on Facebook. The massacre led to a global call to combat the spread of violent content.
articles.abstract: When 51 people were killed in New Zealand, the suspect broadcast it live on Facebook. The massacre led to a global call to combat the spread of violent content.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When 51 people were killed in Christchurch, New Zealand, in March, the suspect, an Australian man, broadcast the attack live on Facebook. The video spread across the internet.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz and Adam Satariano

articles.headline: The Global Economy Was Improving. Then the Fighting Resumed.
articles.snippet: The escalating trade war between the United States and China is threatening the global economy.
articles.abstract: The escalating trade war between the United States and China is threatening the global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In ordinary times, worries about the health of the global economy tend to prompt leaders of the largest countries to join forces in pursuit of safety.
